SUMMARY:

TEXT:
A still image from a video posted by the Taliban on social media on December 19, 2016 shows American Caitlan Coleman (L) speaking next to her Canadian husband Joshua Boyle and their two sons. Courtesy Taliban/Social media via REUTERS

Reuters -- A kidnapped U.S.-Canadian couple and their three children born in captivity have been freed in Pakistan, nearly five years after the couple was abducted in neighbouring Afghanistan, Pakistani and U.S. officials said on Thursday.

American Caitlan Coleman and her Canadian husband, Joshua Boyle, were kidnapped while backpacking in Afghanistan in 2012 by the Taliban-allied Haqqani network, which the United States has long accused Pakistan of failing to fight.

U.S. President Donald Trump, who has been highly critical of Islamabad, praised Pakistan's cooperation with the U.S. government over the freeing of the hostages, saying it represented "a positive moment" for U.S.-Pakistan relations.

"The Pakistani government's cooperation is a sign that it is honoring America's wishes for it to do more to provide security in the region," Trump said in a statement.

Trump's chief of staff, John Kelly, drove home the dire conditions that the family had been subjected to during its long captivity.

"They've been essentially living in a hole for five years," Kelly said. "That's the kind of people we're dealing with over there."

It was unclear how precisely the Pakistani military secured the family's release, which came after the United States shared intelligence about the hostages' location. It was also unclear when the family would return home.

A U.S soldier climbs a hill with a heavy rucksack In Afghanistan in 2012

Two U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, told Reuters that the U.S. military had been ready to fly the family out of the country but said Boyle, who is Canadian, had refused to board the aircraft.

Boyle had once been married to the sister of an inmate at the U.S. military detention center at Guantanamo Bay. The marriage ended and the inmate was later released to Canada.

As of Thursday evening, there was no indication the family had left Pakistan. Boyle's parents said he told them by phone he would see them in a couple of days.

"So we're waiting for that," his mother, Linda Boyle, said in a video posted on the Toronto Star newspaper's website.

Canadian Joshua Boyle's parents say their son, family held captive for years in Afghanistan will return to Canada https://t.co/UIyqi98mQe pic.twitter.com/fFIOUfnzaL â€” The National (@CBCTheNational) October 13, 2017

U.S. officials expressed hope that the hostages' freedom could represent a turning point in relations between Pakistan and the United States, uneasy allies in fighting Taliban and other Islamist extremists in the region.

In recent days, senior U.S. officials have been more pointed about Islamabad's alleged ties to militant groups, who are battling against U.S. and U.S.-backed forces in a stalemated 16-year-old war in neighboring Afghanistan. Some U.S. officials say Pakistani safe havens have helped prolong the conflict.

Pakistan fiercely denies such ties, and it touted the operation as proof of the strength of the alliance.

"The success underscores the importance of timely intelligence sharing and Pakistan's continued commitment towards fighting this menace through cooperation between two forces against a common enemy," a Pakistani army statement said.

Boyle's father, in the video message, offered his thanks to Pakistani forces "who risked their lives and got all five of ours out safely and rescued."

The Toronto Star reported that Boyle told his parents that he was in the trunk of the kidnappers' car with his wife and children when they were rescued by Pakistani forces. Boyle said he sustained minor shrapnel wounds during the shootout, which left his kidnappers dead.

"The last words Boyle said he heard from the kidnappers were, 'kill the hostages,'" the Star reported.

The Pakistani army said its forces were able to recover the hostages after acting on U.S. intelligence about their passage into Pakistan from Afghanistan.

The White House, Pentagon and State Department did not offer details about the Pakistani effort, even as it praised cooperation from Islamabad.

Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland asked for respect for the family's privacy.

"Joshua, Caitlan, their children and the Boyle and Coleman families have endured a horrible ordeal over the past five years. We stand ready to support them as they begin their healing journey," Freeland said.

Trudeau says Canadian hostage Joshua Boyle still on government radar pic.twitter.com/KrLDBRhFLU â€” Globalnews.ca (@globalnews) September 26, 2017

Coleman was pregnant at the time she was kidnapped, and a video released by the Taliban in December showed two sons born while she and her husband were hostages. Thursday's statements from Islamabad and Washington were the first mention of a third child.

Some officials said Pakistanis' motive for freeing the hostages may have been political rather than humanitarian, intended to reduce the tensions ahead of upcoming visits by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis.

Tillerson in a statement said Trump's strategy in the region recognized "the important role Pakistan needs to play to bring stability and ultimately peace to the region."

Mattis, who last week said the United States would try "one more time" to work with Pakistan in Afghanistan, was upbeat on Thursday.

"This is a very positive moment and the Pakistan army performed well," Mattis told reporters during a trip to Florida.

(Reporting by Asif Shahzad; Additional reporting by Phil Stewart in Washington; Idrees Ali in Tampa, Florida; Andrea Hopkins in Ottawa; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Lisa Shumaker)
TITLE: Kidnapped By The Taliban, Couple And Three Children Freed After Five Years

SUMMARY:
For the first time since undergoing bypass heart surgery, he's spoken about the importance of living in the moment and how the idea of being a man means talking about feelings and mental health.
So what I do for my mental health -- what I know now having been through that more than once -- I recognise the triggers and I recognise what puts me back into that position.
Andrew Denton has given a health update after undergoing heart bypass surgery.
And while that brought about a particular level of mental stress, he told Garone that he finds value for his own mental health in "the elemental business of being alive".
That men from his father's generation simply didn't talk about mental health issues and males from his son's generation are much happier to dive into conversations about feelings.
TEXT:
Just two months ago Australian media personality Andrew Denton was diagnosed with advanced heart disease. For the first time since undergoing bypass heart surgery, he's spoken about the importance of living in the moment and how the idea of being a man means talking about feelings and mental health.

The 57-year-old comedian spoke to Adam Garone, the co-founder of the Movember Foundation, in a podcast interview and revealed how he has learnt throughout his career to recognise his triggers for poor mental health.

"When I was younger, I had issues with depression. It wasn't until my 30s that I actually got a diagnosis or even understood what it was," he said.

"There was no real conversation about it. So what I do for my mental health -- what I know now having been through that more than once -- I recognise the triggers and I recognise what puts me back into that position. So, I act on that.

"The triggers are generally if I completely overstress myself and get very run down, that can lead to that depressive sense."

As a result of his triple bypass heart surgery, Denton -- who is also a director of the assisted dying advocacy group Go Gentle Australia -- was forced to step aside in recent months from that organisation and media responsibilities.

Denton began Go Gentle in 2016 after seeing his father, prominent Australia broadcaster, writer and author of 'Breaker Morant' Kit Denton, die slowly and painfully two decades prior from heart failure.

Andrew Denton has given a health update after undergoing heart bypass surgery. #Studio10 pic.twitter.com/6QFAu2g4Md â€” Studio 10 (@Studio10au) October 9, 2017

Denton had made it his life's work to lobby for law reform for terminally ill people. And while that brought about a particular level of mental stress, he told Garone that he finds value for his own mental health in "the elemental business of being alive".

"When I was going through very depressive times, one of the things that enabled me to keep stepping forward was to reminding myself ofâ€”and this sounds very Hallmark greeting cardâ€”but literally of the beauty of a sunset or literally the amazingness of a flower," he said.

"Think, whatever other s--t is happening in the world, how extraordinary to, for however long I'm alive, to be able to experience these miraculous things. That's what I mean about the elemental business of being alive.

"Whether there's a God or not, I don't know. We are a part of the universe, a series of atoms that's coalesced for some reason into this conscious being, and we have the opportunity to experience the amazingness of the physical world."

Is it time to introduce voluntary assisted dying laws? @gogentle_aus' Andrew Denton speaks about their film #StopTheHorror. #TheProjectTV pic.twitter.com/DcPdGh60r5 â€” The Project (@theprojecttv) September 14, 2017

In the podcast, the television personality also spoke about his father's influence on him when it comes to thinking about masculinity and how he can convey that to his own son, Connor.

And the thing that stood out the most for him? That men from his father's generation simply didn't talk about mental health issues and males from his son's generation are much happier to dive into conversations about feelings.

"I think my dad being of his generation from England, he wasn't raised in a tradition of sharing your feelings. I think intellectually he knew how to do that," he said.

"But I would say that men today -- not across the board -- are much better at having that conversation... than my dad's generation was.

"It's still an issue and it's been great in recent years to see footballers, for example, who are strong masculine role models, start to talk openly about the kind of problems they have. One of the reasons I'm very proud of my son is that I have seen from a young age he's deeply empathetic to his friends and offers himself to be there."

Andrew Denton said modelling might be his next career move -- at least he has the pose on point.

As for his next step into the future, he told Garone that he's looking forward to enjoying life -- even fitting in time for a quick laugh about his possible next career move.

"Look, I always transition [in his career], but for me I have a philosophy that life is the career, not the other way around," he said.

"In fact, when this is done, I'm really looking forward to stepping back out of the square.

"I think male modelling is my next step."

If you need help in a crisis, call Lifeline on 13 11 14. For further information about anxiety or depression contact beyondblue on 1300224636 or talk to your GP, local health professional or someone you trust.
TITLE: Andrew Denton Opens Up About Mental Health And Masculinity

BedrÃ¤ngen die USA die TÃ¼rkei von Bulgarien aus?

Die kleinere Zeitung "AydÄ±nlÄ±k" berichtete indes gar von einem US-amerikanischen Plan, die TÃ¼rkei militÃ¤risch von Norden unter Druck zu setzen.

Die USA hÃ¤tten demnach amerikanische Soldaten von RumÃ¤nien Ã¼ber Bulgarien Richtung tÃ¼rkische Grenze geschickt. 2500 Soldaten seien demnach in Bulgarien stationiert, einige nur 60 Kilometer von der tÃ¼rkischen Grenze entfernt.

"Es geht darum, die TÃ¼rkei zu umzingeln", schreibt die Zeitung.

In anderen tÃ¼rkischen Medien ist die Rede von einem kurdischen Korridor gegen die TÃ¼rkei, den die USA errichte. Gemeint sind die kurdisch kontrollierten Gebiete im Norden des Iraks und Syriens, wo die USA verschiedene Kurden-Gruppierungen unterstÃ¼tzt.

Auch Erdogan bediente am Donnerstag VerschwÃ¶rungstheorien gegen die USA.

Es gebe "eine Fraktion der alten Regierung, die versucht unsere Beziehung zu torpedieren", sagte der tÃ¼rkische PrÃ¤sident. FÃ¼r die Eskalation sei also die Obama-FÃ¼hrung verantwortlich.

(ll)
TITLE: "Der IS handelt unter FÃ¼hrung der USA": TÃ¼rkische Medien werfen dem US-Botschafter eine VerschwÃ¶rung vor

SUMMARY:
Ce qui aurait conduit, selon la presse sus-nommÃ©e, Ã  conduire Trouville quasiment au bord de la banqueroute !
Quel est le cinglÃ© qui a ainsi laissÃ© filÃ© le budget, qui plus est en temps de crise ?
Sauf que lÃ  oÃ¹ le scÃ©nario dÃ©raille, c'est que le dingue censÃ© gaspiller l'argent public (moi) n'est pas rÃ©munÃ©rÃ© pour "ambiancer" la ville en lui crÃ©ant un festival!
MÃªme repeinte Ã  la hÃ¢te par notre jeune prÃ©sident, La "France moisie" (chÃ¨re Ã  Sollers) affleure toujours: elle dÃ©teste tout ce qui est nouveau, gÃ©nÃ©reux ou audacieux.
Elle sent la mort, cette France des rond-points et des bacs fleuris, des napperons sur la tÃ©lÃ© et des haines recuites, celle qui se tait et qui aime dÃ©noncer.
TEXT:
Rien n'a changÃ© depuis 1934, date Ã  laquelle Gabriel Chevalier publia "Clochemerle", son roman satirique. NaÃ¯vement, j'ai cru que cette Ã©poque de petites bassesses entre Ã©lus de province Ã©tait rÃ©volue; que ces pauvres querelles autour du moindre Ã©dicule urinatoire appartenaient au passÃ©... Dans notre France "disruptÃ©e" par un prÃ©sident de 39 ans, comment penser que cela pouvait encore exister ? Et pourtant...

Moi qui voue un culte Ã  la politique, au cinÃ©ma, et comme une majoritÃ© de mes concitoyens*, estime que la politique c'est surtout du cinÃ©ma... j'ai Ã©tÃ© victime de ma propre inclination et suis devenu, malgrÃ© moi, l'acteur d'un navet ! Un nanar qui a eu les honneurs de la presse locale puis carrÃ©ment du "Canard", au travers d'une critique ma foi fort Ã©logieuse.

L'histoire: dans une magnifique station balnÃ©aire normande, Trouville-sur-Mer, j'eu l'excellente idÃ©e de lancer, voici deux ans, le Festival International du Film Culte - excellente car aprÃ¨s tout... personne ne l'avait eu avant. L'idÃ©e donc, outre le plaisir de cÃ©lÃ©brer des monuments "cultissimes" du cinÃ©ma et de favoriser l'Ã©mergence de futurs films culte*, Ã©tait d'aider les Trouvillais Ã  sortir la ville du dÃ©ficit de notoriÃ©tÃ© que fait peser sur elle son imposante voisine, Deauville. Ce qui aurait conduit, selon la presse sus-nommÃ©e, Ã  conduire Trouville quasiment au bord de la banqueroute ! Que s'est-il passÃ© ? Pourquoi l'apport industrie de la mairie a-t-il coÃ»tÃ© 38.000â‚¬ de plus que prÃ©vu? Quel est le cinglÃ© qui a ainsi laissÃ© filÃ© le budget, qui plus est en temps de crise ? L'intrigue est indÃ©niablement palpitante, prometteuse de moult rebondissements ! Voici Clochemerle sur mer, son univers impitoyable. Air connu.

Les personnages: un respectable magistrat Ã  la Cour des Comptes, Maire de Trouville depuis bien trop longtemps au goÃ»t de sa conseillÃ¨re municipale d'opposition, prÃ©maturÃ©ment retraitÃ©e d'une presse flageolante, qui s'est jurÃ© de le remplacer. Des lustres qu'elle s'y emploie, ayant beaucoup de temps libre. Pour cela, bien sÃ»r, tout lui est bon, car comme disait Chirac "Plus c'est gros, plus Ã§a passe" ! Au milieu, votre serviteur, cible idÃ©ale pour faire les frais de l'Ã©ternel adage de tout conseil municipal qui se respecte: subventions = dÃ©rapages!

Sauf que lÃ  oÃ¹ le scÃ©nario dÃ©raille, c'est que le dingue censÃ© gaspiller l'argent public (moi) n'est pas rÃ©munÃ©rÃ© pour "ambiancer" la ville en lui crÃ©ant un festival! Il est bÃ©nÃ©vole, au sein d'une association Ã  but non lucratif! Et que l'apport industrie de la mairie, ce n'est Ã©videmment pas lui qui le gÃ¨re. Mais qu'importe!

Haro sur le ZÃ©ro pour Ã©pingler le maire!

Qu'importe le flacon, pourvu qu'on ait l'ivresse... du pouvoir!

HÃ©las, on dÃ©grise vite. Le soufflÃ© au Calvados retombe lamentablement. Dans cette saga qui s'annonÃ§ait riche en dÃ©nonciations, en mensonges et en rÃ¨glements de comptes saignants, dans ce futur Levallois sur mer, les dialogues se rÃ©vÃ¨lent affligeants de mÃ©diocritÃ©. Faut dire qu'ils sont bÃ¢clÃ©s, Ã©crits avec le coude par deux "plumitives", rageuses pour d'obscurs raisons ("Mais enfin je n'ai pas reÃ§u mon invitation au concert de Michel Legrand organisÃ© par votre Festival !" tÃ©moignant de l'Ã©tat d'esprit rabougri qui rÃ¨gne toujours dans ces mÃ©dias locaux aux ordres de cÃ©nacles d'Ã©diles en mal de reconnaissance. MÃªme repeinte Ã  la hÃ¢te par notre jeune prÃ©sident, La "France moisie" (chÃ¨re Ã  Sollers) affleure toujours: elle dÃ©teste tout ce qui est nouveau, gÃ©nÃ©reux ou audacieux. Elle sent la mort, cette France des rond-points et des bacs fleuris, des napperons sur la tÃ©lÃ© et des haines recuites, celle qui se tait et qui aime dÃ©noncer. Elle n'a rien de culte, et je n'ai rien Ã  lui dire. Sauf merde, mais je suis poli.

*pour 73% d'entre eux, selon un sondage Opinion Way.

*culte est invariable
TITLE: La France moisie fait son festival!

SUMMARY:
(Photo by Stringer/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images)ADVERTISEMENTEven as thousands of Rohingya Muslims are fleeing Myanmar to escape violence and persecution at the hands of the country's military and police, the chief of India's premier body on social sciences believes they should not be tolerated in India.
Speaking at the public event, Kumar said, "This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."
"This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."
Thorat as the head of the ICSSR, an autonomous body established by the Indian government in 1969 to promote social studies research.
The Hindu further reported that Kumar had also claimed that Rajput king Prithviraj Chauhan beat Ghori 17 times but did not kill him.
TEXT:
COXS BAZAR, BANGLADESH OCTOBER 11: 4-year-old Rohingya kid Shehna starts journey from Myanmar on the shoulder of his father, to the refugee camp at Balukhali in Coxs Bazar, Bangladesh on October 11, 2017. (Photo by Stringer/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images)

ADVERTISEMENT

Even as thousands of Rohingya Muslims are fleeing Myanmar to escape violence and persecution at the hands of the country's military and police, the chief of India's premier body on social sciences believes they should not be tolerated in India.

The Hindu today reported on the remarks made by Braj Bihari Kumar, who heads the Indian Council of Social Science Research (ICSSR), at a seminar recently organized by the Indian Council of Historical Research (ICHR).

Speaking at the public event, Kumar said, "This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."

"This nation should not tolerate them as part of India."

Earlier this year, Kumar succeeded prominent academic S.K. Thorat as the head of the ICSSR, an autonomous body established by the Indian government in 1969 to promote social studies research.

Kumar, 76, served has the editor of two journals, Dialogue and Chintan Srijan, published by Astha Bharati, a non-profit organisation dedicated to promoting "India's unity and integrity."

The online news outlet, Scroll, has previously reported on the opinions that Kumar has professed over the course of years, including, "There is none in India, who has suffered more due to intolerance than Narendra Modi."

Kumar's remarks come at a time when the Modi government is making a legal case to deport Rohingya Muslim refugees from India, branding them as national security threat. The central government's position has been condemned by human rights activists and lawyers who argue that even those who are not citizens are guaranteed protection under the Indian Constitution when they are on Indian soil.

"There is none in India, who has suffered more due to intolerance than Narendra Modi."

Speaking at the ICHR event, Kumar said, "We should like to know about the Rohingyas also. What is their record? In 1943, when war was going on between the British and the Japanese, the British government of Burma supplied arms and ammunitions to the Rohingyas to fight against the Japanese, and the Rohingyas turned the gun towards the Buddhists," he said.

"How can Burmese forget such enemies? They are not fools like Indians. The Burmese remember their enemies,"" Kumar continued. "My point is that we can't placate illegal migrants. We should not do it. This nation should not tolerate them as a part of India."

The Hindu further reported that Kumar had also claimed that Rajput king Prithviraj Chauhan beat Ghori 17 times but did not kill him. The newspaper pointed out that history tells us there were only two battles.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: India Should Not Tolerate Rohingya Muslims, Says Chief Of Premier Social Sciences Body

Lluc kÃ¤mpft fÃ¼r die die katalanische UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit, Foto: Michael TrammerEr sieht die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit als einzige Chance, um einen Schlussstrich zu ziehen.
Doch was ist dran an den kritischen Stimmen, die die Separatisten fÃ¼r gefÃ¤hrliche Nationalisten halten?
Denn sie haben das GefÃ¼hl, dass von der wirtschaftlichen StÃ¤rke der Region wenig bei ihnen ankommt.
Auf die eine oder andere Art und Weise wird es in Llucs Augen eine Konfrontation zwischen der spanischen und der katalanischen Regierung geben.
TEXT:
Die Lage in Barcelona scheint sich beruhigt zu haben â€“ doch die Katalanen streben weiter nach UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit

Junge Aktivisten bereiten sich auf einen lÃ¤ngeren politischen Kampf vor

Die HuffPost berichtet aus Barcelona: Wie geht es dort nun weiter?

Barcelona im Oktober 2017. Ganz Europa blickt auf die Metropole im Nordosten Spaniens, als am Mittwoch den 5. Oktober PrÃ¤sident Puidgemont eine Art "UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit Light" ausruft. Er erklÃ¤rt die Abspaltung von Spanien â€“ und setzt den Prozess dann gleich wieder aus.



Der spanische Staat hatte Ã¼ber Monate hinweg versucht, ein Referendum zu verhindern. Deshalb wurden im Verborgenen Urnen gefertigt, nach Katalonien geschmuggelt und in Wahllokale gebracht. Am Tag des Referendums kam es zur Konfrontation.



Aktivisten besetzten Schulen, um dort die Abstimmung zu ermÃ¶glichen, Foto: Michael Trammer



Ungeheuerliche Bilder von Polizeigewalt gingen um die Welt. Nun scheint sich die Lage zu beruhigen. Die aufrÃ¼hrerischen Katalanen, die nach Sezession rufen, wollen an den Verhandlungstisch. Die Zentralregierung bleibt hart und will klare Kante zeigen: Kein Dialog mit denen, die sie als Verfassungsfeinde brandmarken.



Doch was sind die Motive junger Leute sich trotz aller Hindernisse, trotz der drohenden Gewaltspirale der UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung anzuschlieÃŸen? Was sind die Hoffnungen in einen neu-gegrÃ¼ndeten Staat? Wie bereiten sich die Menschen auf die drohende Konfrontation vor?



"Kein Blut-und-Boden-Nationalismus"



Lluc ist Kunststudent an der UniversitÃ¤t in Barcelona. Er hat geholfen, das Referendum durchzufÃ¼hren, auch durch die Besetzung von Schulen, die dann als Wahllokale dienten. FÃ¼r ihn bedeutet eine Sezession von Spanien, deutlich mehr als nur die GrÃ¼ndung eines neuen Staates.



Lluc kÃ¤mpft fÃ¼r die die katalanische UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit, Foto: Michael Trammer



Er sieht die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit als einzige Chance, um einen Schlussstrich zu ziehen. Auch mit dem in seinen Augen ungenÃ¼gend aufgearbeiteten Erbe des Francoregimes. Seine Hoffnung und Anspruch an einen katalanischen Staat ist vor allem: Mehr direkte Demokratie â€“ ein basisdemokratischer Staat.

Doch was ist dran an den kritischen Stimmen, die die Separatisten fÃ¼r gefÃ¤hrliche Nationalisten halten?

Lluc zumindest streitet das vorsichtig ab. Laut seiner EinschÃ¤tzung handelt es sich bei der katalanischen Ideologie nicht um einen Blut-und-Boden Nationalismus. FÃ¼r ihn ist Katalane wer sich zum multikulturellen Leben in der spanischen Region zugehÃ¶rig fÃ¼hlt. Lluc gibt aber auch zu, dass sicher nicht alle Leute in der UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitsbewegung so denken wie er.

"Ich rede Ã¼ber eine soziale Revolution!"



Die wirtschaftlichen Konsequenzen, die Katalonien bereits jetzt zu spÃ¼ren bekommt, kÃ¼mmern ihn nicht. Mehrere Banken haben ihre Sitze aus der Region verlagert. Jobs werden gekÃ¼ndigt.



Eine Frau beim Public Viewing â€“ kurz bevor das Ergebnis des Referendums verkÃ¼ndet wurde

Lluc ist das egal. Er trÃ¤umt ohnehin davon, dass sich alles Ã¤ndert: "Ich rede hier Ã¼ber eine soziale Revolution! Die allererste Grundbedingung fÃ¼r genau so eine ist, dass Banken aus Katalonien verschwinden mÃ¼ssen und wir die Steuerung der Wirtschaft selbst in die Hand nehmen!â€œ

Es ist eine radikale Position, die viele Katalanen teilen. Denn sie haben das GefÃ¼hl, dass von der wirtschaftlichen StÃ¤rke der Region wenig bei ihnen ankommt. TatsÃ¤chlich ist die Arbeitslosenquote in Katalonien, nach der Eurokrise kaum niedriger als im Rest von Spanien.

Auf die eine oder andere Art und Weise wird es in Llucs Augen eine Konfrontation zwischen der spanischen und der katalanischen Regierung geben. Er geht auch davon aus, dass die katalanische Regierung in naher Zukunft ihre realpolitische Macht verlieren wird. Dann wÃ¤re auch ein MilitÃ¤reinsatz in Katalonien denkbar.

"Es wird groÃŸe Generalstreiks geben!"

Wie genau es weitergeht, kann auch der Aktivist nicht absehen. Was seine Freunde und er planen, wenn die UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit final erklÃ¤rt wird, weiÃŸ er aber genau: â€˜Wir haben unsere KrÃ¤fte bereits vorbereitet und es wird Streiks geben â€“ Generalstreiks! Ein Datum kann ich euch nicht nennen â€“ aber es wird bald Generalstreiks geben! GroÃŸe Generalstreiks!â€œ



Tausende junge Katalanen trÃ¤umen von der UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit.

Diese sollen wohl auch einen verfassungsbildenden Prozess befÃ¼rworten und beschleunigen. In seinen Augen, kann die Zentralregierung in Madrid zwar das MilitÃ¤r nach Katalonien schicken. Doch wie sollen sie gegen die Massen auf den StraÃŸen vorgehen?

Gewaltsame Ausschreitungen in den StraÃŸen von Barcelona wÃ¤ren auch fÃ¼r die spanische Regierung ein Fiasko.



AuszuschlieÃŸen sind sie nicht: Denn die Lage in Katalonien scheint ganz und gar nicht beruhigt. Zwar sind die Protestwellen abgeebbt und momentan findet ein Konflikt auf parteipolitischer Ebene statt, doch erst am Donnerstagabend riefen nun auch bÃ¼rgerliche Gruppen zu einer finalen Lossagung von Madrid auf.

Die zunehmende Geschlossenheit der katalanischen Bewegung kÃ¶nnte ihren Drang nach Freiheit weiter befeuern.
TITLE: "Ich rede Ã¼ber eine Revolution": Wie sich junge Katalanen auf eine Konfrontation mit Madrid vorbereiten

SUMMARY:
If Sophie and Apollo weren't attractive enough their date basically involved getting into a pen full of puppies.
A woman wandered over to Apollo and Sophie and spritzed them with "love spray", something that'll get you kicked out of a Coles.
Whatever it was, Sophie wasn't feeling the vibe and DIDN'T give Sammy a rose on their games date.
Speaking of weird: this rose ceremony was BONKERS.
Two bachelors weren't going to get roses and quickly Jarrod, Stu and James all joined Apollo in the rose brigade, leaving Blake, Sam and AJ behind.
TEXT:
We apologise to anyone who may have realised we missed possibly the most explosive episode of 'The Bachelorette' so far which saw Sophie saying goodbye to Luke, an incredibly handsome frontrunner.

We were too, as the kids would say, shook AF to even begin to piece things together. That being said, so were the bachelors, as they mourned Luke's departure and most likely eventual appearance on 'Bachelor In Paradise'.

Uncle Sam deemed himself "the next frontrunner" which is like Abraham Lincoln calling himself the best audience member the theatre has ever seen. Don't get too ahead of yourself mate.

Thankfully the most handsome magician in the house, Apollo, nabbed the single date. Uncle Sam called the muscular, handsome and kind Apollo "a dark horse" which is fine if you think the definition of "dark horse" is "perfect man".

Excuse us we just have a lot of fanfic to write about this.

If Sophie and Apollo weren't attractive enough their date basically involved getting into a pen full of puppies. They decided to do "Doga" which, before you get too excited, is doggy yoga. A woman wandered over to Apollo and Sophie and spritzed them with "love spray", something that'll get you kicked out of a Coles.

The pair did yoga with two of the fluffiest, cutest dogs and we stress-ate an entire tub of ice cream because of all the feelings.

Sophie and Apollo shared stories about being creative types. "I used to have a mouse costume and one time I just sat really still for hours," Sophie admitted. "My best friend was a girl and we used to hunt fairies," Apollo told her.

Honestly this is why no one likes creative types.

Back at the house Blake, one of the few boys yet to have a single date with Sophie, was concerned he wasn't getting enough time with her. He greeted her on the group date by telling her she had a "sick outfit". Men are so strange.

Osher informed the bachelors that they were about to compete in a boat race. Jarrod, the most competitive bachelor in history, was ready to throw his own team into the ocean.

Jarrod is the first man to find a way to power a boat purely from sheer competitiveness and screaming.

"GO, GO, GO, GO" Jarrod screamed at everything on the boat. "GO, GO, GO" he shouted at a pile of ropes. Meanwhile Blake decided to give Sophie a massage.

"I love competition," Jarrod said before noting that the ocean was wet and the sky was blue. "I love competition," Jarrod said like Scrooge McDuck would admit to loving money.

Unfortunately, despite all his incessant screaming at a bunch of ropes, Jarrod didn't win the alone time, Blake did.

As they sipped champagne on the front of a boat in the gorgeous Sydney Harbour Blake looked at Sophie and said, "I really want to kiss you now". Then he turned back to the harbour and stared directly into the sun, searing his eyes as the awkwardness set in of not actually kissing her.

"Ha ha this is not awkward at all," Blake said before snapping his champagne glass in half and eating it.

It was awkward as hell and such a huge missed opportunity for ol' Blakey boy.

Surprisingly this episode featured a THIRD date, possibly because Blake's alone time was so awkward and boring (for both Sophie AND us) Sophie gave Sam his second date. Remember the "double delight rose"? The one Sam wouldn't shut up about? Well he finally got his second single date.

"It's like so tacky it's awesome," Sophie said either describing the hummer limo she picked him up in or his hair.

As Sophie and Sam drove through the countryside in a stretch hummer he kept talking about all his actor friends, his voice over work and how he basically is the best music producer in Australia. Sophie was so impressed she could barely make a facial impression.

Then she took him to play some connect four in a field because Sam is basically what would happen if a teenager had fallen in a coma in the '90s and only just woke up. "Radical, I am so good at Connect Four! Cowabunga dudette!"

Somewhere, Jarrod is screaming "I'M VERY GOOD AT CONNECT FOUR, I LOVE COMPETITION".

The date went on as Sophie tried to quiz Sam about his intentions and why he decided to be on the show. Was it for fame? Was it for her? Was it for the bromance between him and Blake? Whatever it was, Sophie wasn't feeling the vibe and DIDN'T give Sammy a rose on their games date.

As Sophie entered the cocktail party Jarrod described her as "Black Swan all over," a film where Natalie Portman wants to be so good at ballet she goes crazy and dies. Okay mate.

We then had to talk about Jarrod's love plant for ANOTHER DAY. The good news, however, is that his little plant was finally growing. "Oh, mine's like massive... mine's overtaken yours but it's still good," she said pitifully.

"It bodes well for me that Sophie is impressed by minimal growth," Jarrod thought.

Blake and Sam had a really weird chat where they both decided that they'd love to be the final two because they both believe Sophie would be "safe" in the other's hands. It was... kind of creepy and weird.

Speaking of weird: this rose ceremony was BONKERS.

Two bachelors weren't going to get roses and quickly Jarrod, Stu and James all joined Apollo in the rose brigade, leaving Blake, Sam and AJ behind. There were a few swear words (sorry Ryan, we know you don't like swears!) as she dropped an immense bombshell.

Sophie dismissed AJ because, like who cares. Then she approached Sam and Blake, the two remaining bachelors. "Do I know the real you, Sam?" "Blake, most of our time together I didn't think you liked me," she said to both of them.

Excuse us we just have a lot of fanfic to write about this.

She then walked back to the rose and... gave it to Blake!!!!

It was the end for Uncle Sam who could Connect Four but couldn't connect the dots.
TITLE: Ok, That Was The Most Bonkers Rose Ceremony In 'Bachelorette' History
Estados Unidos se retira de la UNESCO

SUMMARY:
But more research is showing the connection between what we eat and depression, and new research has validated this.
In other words, the Risk Index for Depression is about prevention.
It confirms that diet is one of the most important to asses the risk of depression.
"Interestingly, in somatic symptoms (which included symptoms of pain, liver and hearing) what dominated was the bowels.
"Adolescents would go to their clinician and work out their Risk Index and where it's most affecting their risk -- is it their diet, lifestyle, stressful event?"
TEXT:
When we're sitting down to eat a meal, most of us don't think about how food could affect our mental health. But more research is showing the connection between what we eat and depression, and new research has validated this.

Using a first-of-its-kind 'Risk Index for Depression' to assess how different behaviours affect the risk of depression, the research found that our diet is the most important contributor to mental health, followed by other factors like sleep and exercise.

The research, predominantly done through IMPACT SRC at Deakin University in collaboration with Swinburne University, confirms that depression is not caused by one simple factor or event, but rather various factors which, if identified for each young person, could help clinicians recognise the early signs of depression. In other words, the Risk Index for Depression is about prevention.

Considering depression is a global health concern -- with one in six people to experience depression at some point in their life which will affect their wellbeing, personal relationships, work life and productivity -- the Risk Index for Depression shows promise as a tool to add (or remove) direct or indirect risks.

To understand more about the risk determinants for depression, HuffPost Australia spoke to the Risk Index for Depression (RID) developer and Swinburne lecturer in the Department of Statistics, Data Science and Epidemiology, Joanna Dipnall.

"We utilised a large database from the U.S. which has a huge amount of information about people's diet, lifestyle and self-reported medical symptoms," Dipnall said.

"We spent time compartmentalising each of the risk determinants for depression, which include diet, lifestyle, environs, biomarkers and somatic symptoms, and for each of those we put into a probability of depression and built this into a structural model of the RID to see if we could determine an overall risk of depression and isolate the important elements.

"What we found confirms that depression is not a simple condition -- it is complicated and multifaceted. It confirms that diet is one of the most important to asses the risk of depression. Diet has a direct path."

A healthy diet with plenty of plant-based foods is incredibly important -- not just for physical health but mental health.

In the research, under each main risk determinant there are predicted probabilities of depression. Lifestyle included sleep, weight and exercise; demographics included gender, rage and age; biomarkers included red cell distribution risk; somatic symptoms included pain, bowels and thyroid; and diet included fruit, vegetable and whole grain intake.

A key finding from the research is that a person is more likely to become depressed if their diet is poor, their lifestyle is erratic and they do not exercise.

"Interestingly, in somatic symptoms (which included symptoms of pain, liver and hearing) what dominated was the bowels. This also ties into diet," Dipnall told HuffPost Australia.

"The team at Deakin University in the Food and Mood Centre are looking even further into this in isolation and have already found dietary fibre being central to gut health. My research is further confirming this."

Certain dietary patterns influence parts of the brain, namely the hippocampus which is important for mental health.

So, what's comes next?

"This is the first stage. The RID is modular so we want to build on this model to include the important aspects of factors such as 'stressful life event'," Dipnall said.

"It's not yet ready and needs more research, but ultimately the RID is about a predisposition to depression. What we want to do is be able to look at younger people and intervene based on their Risk Index with the best targeted intervention."

Essentially, in the future clinicians may be able to use this tool to work out a young person's predisposition for depression and identify their various individual determinants.

"Adolescents would go to their clinician and work out their Risk Index and where it's most affecting their risk -- is it their diet, lifestyle, stressful event?" Dipnall explained.

"A lot of people talk about depression and say, 'You've got to do this to help your mood', but nobody has really tried to bring it together to say, 'Yes there's diet, yes there's lifestyle, and yes you have these somatic symptoms'."

If you need help in a crisis, call Lifeline on 13 11 14. For further information about depression contact beyondblue on 1300224636 or talk to your GP, local health professional or someone you trust.
TITLE: Is Diet Linked To Depression? This Research Confirms It Again

SUMMARY:
Four French citizens survived the crash but were injured, Ivory Coastâ€™s Security Minister Sidiki Diakite told reporters at the scene.
Several Ivorian security sources said French soldiers were among the wounded.
â€œThis was a plane chartered by the French army in the framework of the Barkhane force in order to carry out logistical missions,â€ French army spokesman Colonel Patrick Steiger said.
Franceâ€™s ambassador to Ivory Coast along with French gendarmes and soldiers quickly arrived at the crash site.
French soldiers and Ivorian security forces later sealed off the area and French and Ivorian military vessels patrolled waters surrounding the crash site.
TEXT:
Four Moldovan citizens were killed and two others were injured when a cargo plane chartered by the French military crashed into the sea near the airport in Ivory Coastâ€™s main city, Abidjan, on Saturday, Ivorian and French officials said.

Four French citizens survived the crash but were injured, Ivory Coastâ€™s Security Minister Sidiki Diakite told reporters at the scene. Several Ivorian security sources said French soldiers were among the wounded.

â€œWhat we can say for the time being is that this morning around 8:30 (0830 GMT), an Antonov plane crashed...with 10 on board including the crew members,â€ he said.

The crash occurred during a storm with heavy rain and lightning and rescuers were hampered by rough seas. Though Abidjanâ€™s airport is located in a heavily populated area, it did not appear that anyone was hurt on the ground.

The French military operates a logistics base next to the airport in support of its Barkhane operation, combating Islamist militants in West Africaâ€™s Sahel region.

â€œThis was a plane chartered by the French army in the framework of the Barkhane force in order to carry out logistical missions,â€ French army spokesman Colonel Patrick Steiger said.

Reuters Staff/Reuters Rescuers pull the wreckage of the cargo plane on Oct. 14.

It was not immediately clear what caused the plane to crash, he said, adding that the four injured French citizens were being treated at the French military base adjacent to the airport.

Franceâ€™s ambassador to Ivory Coast along with French gendarmes and soldiers quickly arrived at the crash site.

Hundreds of residents of the heavily populated neighborhood of Port Bouet, which surrounds the airport, crowded around the crash site. Some of them assisted firefighters and rescue divers who freed the bodies of the dead from the wreckage, which had broken into several large pieces.

French soldiers and Ivorian security forces later sealed off the area and French and Ivorian military vessels patrolled waters surrounding the crash site.

The name of the company operating the aircraft was not immediately known.
TITLE: French Army Charter Plane Crashes In Ivory Coast

TEXT:
El director de cine estadounidense Oliver Stone dijo este viernes que Harvey Weinstein, el productor de Hollywood acusado de abusos sexuales y violaciÃ³n, estÃ¡ "condenado por un sistema de justicieros".

"Yo soy de la teorÃ­a que hay que esperar hasta que esto llegue a un juicio", dijo a los periodistas en BusÃ¡n, Corea del Sur, estimando que la industria cinematogrÃ¡fica y el pÃºblico condenaban prematuramente a Weinstein.

"Si ha infringido la ley saldrÃ¡ a la luz. Para mÃ­ un hombre no deberÃ­a ser condenado por un sistema de justicieros", agregÃ³ Stone, que preside el jurado del festival internacional de cine de esta ciudad surcoreana.

Hollywood estÃ¡ lleno de "historias de terror" pero las acusaciones contra Weinstein, que abarcan varias dÃ©cadas, son por el momento rumores, en opiniÃ³n de Stone.

"No es fÃ¡cil lo que estÃ¡ atravesando. Durante ese perÃ­odo era un rival y no lo conocÃ­a realmente. He escuchado historias de terror sobre todo el mundo en esta industria, o sea que no voy a comentar cotilleos", agregÃ³.

Preguntado tambiÃ©n en BusÃ¡n sobre el caso Weinstein, el director estadounidense Darren Aronofsky se expresÃ³ de forma diferente: "Las agresiones sexuales, del tipo que sean, son inaceptables. Es ilegal. Y eso debe ser combatido por todos. Hombres y mujeres no deben tolerar eso en absoluto", considerÃ³ el director de Black Swan.

Weinstein, uno de los productores mÃ¡s influyentes de Hollywood, cayÃ³ en desgracia desde que el diario The New York Times publicÃ³ el 5 de octubre un explosivo artÃ­culo sobre sus continuos acosos y abusos sexuales a decenas de mujeres, en su mayorÃ­a jÃ³venes actrices y asistentes.

Harvey Weinstein, de 65 aÃ±os, que estÃ¡ siendo investigado por la policÃ­a en Nueva York y en el Reino Unido, fue acusado el jueves de una cuarta violaciÃ³n.

Desde que saliÃ³ a la luz el escÃ¡ndalo que ha conmocionado Hollywood, numerosas actrices, entre ellas Mira Sorvino, Rosana Arquette, Gwyneth Paltrow, Angelina Jolie y LÃ©a Seydoux, han manifestado haber sido objeto de insistentes insinuaciones sexuales del productor.
TITLE: Oliver Stone: Weinstein es vÃ­ctima de 'un sistema de justicieros'

1/3 â€” Twitter Safety (@TwitterSafety) October 12, 2017Here are the women tweeting in solidarity:Join this in solidarity and protest .
Love twitter but need better policies against harassment.
Until tomorrow, #WomenBoycottTwitter.
https://t.co/turRgHHyow â€” Surekha Pillai (@surekhapillai) October 13, 2017I'm participating in #WomenBoycottTwitter in the hopes that it will make Twitter change their harassment policies.
#womenboycotttwitter â€” BookOfGenesia (@genesiaalves) October 13, 2017I'm boycotting twitter tomorrow because women are consistently harassed by accounts who in turn face no consequences.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Friday, 13 October, will be remembered as the day women across the world took a day off from Twitter to protest sexual harassment, the company's apparent inability to contain abuse, and lax security that has, over the years, allowed a colony of vicious trolls to grow and thrive.

#WomenBoycottTwitter was trending nationally in India at 10 AM and women joined hands in solidarity to log off from Twitter â€” a self censorship of sorts â€” to force the social media giant to formulate better policies to control, regulate and punish accounts that issue death, rape and maiming threats to women, stalk them repeatedly and abuse and bully them on a regular basis with no serious consequences.

Women maintained that it will not silence their voices, but will stop Twitter from making money by exploiting them.

Recently, several women wrote to Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey when he announced the newest policy of allowing longer â€” 280 characters, instead of the traditional 140 characters â€” tweets, and asked him to focus on women's safety on the platform instead.

This is a demand that Twitter's faced for years. Malicious, and mostly anonymous, trolling has turned the platform â€” one of the most vibrant communities in the online space for sharing moments, news, views and images â€” into an infestation.

Indian women are hoping that their silent protest will help bring the focus back on the subject.

According to the Guardian, the Twitter boycott started it suspended Rose McGowan, one of the accusers of film producer Harvey Weinstein, who is facing several sexual assault allegations, for violating its terms and policies. It kicked off at midnight in New York.

This was Twitter's response.

We have been in touch with Ms. McGowan's team. We want to explain that her account was temporarily locked because one of her Tweets included a private phone number, which violates our Terms of Service. 1/3 â€” Twitter Safety (@TwitterSafety) October 12, 2017

Here are the women tweeting in solidarity:

I'm logging off Twitter for 24 hours, starting 9:30am IST on Friday, to demand better anti-harassment policy. Join us!#WomenBoycottTwitter â€” Rega Jha (@RegaJha) October 13, 2017

Because as much as I love @twitter, it needs to work out better harassment and suspension policies. Until tomorrow, #WomenBoycottTwitter. ğŸ™ğŸ½ pic.twitter.com/cQZzAiVB1V â€” Deepanjana (@dpanjana) October 13, 2017

#WomenBoycottTwitter. Will be off twitter all day. I love this platform, but I will also be actively pissed off with how callous it's been. pic.twitter.com/L7I0OXB3vu â€” Harnidh//Peglet (@PedestrianPoet) October 13, 2017

joining #WomenBoycottTwitter as commanded by aparna. see you tomorrow. do support this campaign instead of (or in addition to) making jokes. https://t.co/turRgHHyow â€” Surekha Pillai (@surekhapillai) October 13, 2017

TITLE: The Day Indian Women Logged Out Of Twitter To Protest Online Harassment

Nicolas Mesly, reporter et photographe

Hugo Jolion-David, journaliste vidÃ©o

Et puis câ€™est une entreprise agricole de moins sur notre territoire Â», rÃ©sume Jean Poirier, maire de Saint-Basile, un village dâ€™environ 2600 Ã¢mes dans la rÃ©gion de Portneuf, et dont la moitiÃ© de lâ€™Ã©conomie tourne autour de lâ€™agriculture.



Peu avant NoÃ«l dernier, Rudy Ducreux, un jeune agriculteur dâ€™origine franÃ§aise, mettait fin Ã  ses jours en se pendant dans lâ€™atelier de sa ferme, la ferme DucrÃªt, situÃ©e Ã  un jet de pierre de la mairie.



Pour les gens du milieu, ce jeune agriculteur Ã©tait une Ã©toile filante dans le firmament des fromagers quÃ©bÃ©cois. Â« Câ€™Ã©tait quelquâ€™un dâ€™assez rÃ©servÃ©. Mais dÃ¨s que vous parliez dâ€™agriculture, vous constatiez combien il Ã©tait passionnÃ©! Ses fromages au lait cru, dont Le Gaulois de Portneuf, Ã©taient exceptionnels, irremplaÃ§ables. On ne peut pas se permettre de perdre des gens comme lui Â», raconte Charles Trottier, copropriÃ©taire de la Fromagerie Des Grondines qui, partageant la mÃªme profession, lâ€™a bien connu.



Les deux fromagers artisans ont passÃ© Ã  travers la crise de la listÃ©riose de 2008, qui a fait 2 morts et 38 malades, et oÃ¹ le gouvernement a fait jeter aux poubelles des milliers de kilogrammes de fromage. Dans un rapport sur la gestion de cette crise (2010), le ministÃ¨re de lâ€™Agriculture, des PÃªcheries et de lâ€™Alimentation (MAPAQ) exonÃ©rait les fromages au lait cru en identifiant la bactÃ©rie coupable, le pulsovar 93, une souche de la bactÃ©rie Lysteria monocytigene, provenant de fromages au lait pasteurisÃ©. Mais le mal Ã©tait fait, le QuÃ©bec ne compte plus aujourdâ€™hui, avec le dÃ©part de Rudy Ducreux, que quatre ou cinq fromagers au lait cru, selon Normand CÃ´tÃ©, prÃ©sident de lâ€™Association des fromagers artisans du QuÃ©bec, qui regroupe une trentaine de membres.



Pour opÃ©rer notre fromagerie, j'ai besoin de 16 Ã  17 permis diffÃ©rents.

â€“ Charles Trottier



Un mÃ©tier sous trÃ¨s haute tension



Le mÃ©tier de fromager-artisan relÃ¨ve des 12 travaux dâ€™Hercule. Il faut traire des vaches 2 fois par jour, 365 jours par annÃ©e, car on ne peut pas fermer le pis des vaches comme lâ€™eau dâ€™un robinet. Â« Câ€™est trois mÃ©tiers dans un Â», explique Charles Trottier. Sans compter quâ€™il faut composer avec le stress de la mÃ©tÃ©o, la ferme Ã©tant une usine Ã  ciel ouvert, pour produire des fourrages et des grains afin dâ€™alimenter les vaches.

De plus, ce mÃ©tier sâ€™exerce sous une charge administrative kafkaÃ¯enne. Â« Pour opÃ©rer notre fromagerie, jâ€™ai besoin de 16 Ã  17 permis diffÃ©rents, dont un de fabrication du ministÃ¨re de lâ€™Agriculture, un permis du ministÃ¨re de lâ€™Environnement, un permis de transport du lait, de vente au dÃ©tail, de lâ€™organisme de certification biologique, de la municipalitÃ©â€¦ Â» poursuit Charles Trottier.



Comme si cette lourdeur administrative ne suffisait pas, la dÃ©cision du gouvernement Trudeau de permettre lâ€™importation de 16 000 tonnes mÃ©triques de fromages fins en provenance dâ€™Europe dÃ¨s le 21 septembre prochain sous lâ€™Accord Ã©conomique et commercial entre le Canada et lâ€™Union europÃ©enne (AECG) risque de faucher plusieurs fromagers artisanaux du terroir quÃ©bÃ©cois. Â« Cette importation, câ€™est lâ€™Ã©quivalent de 640 fermes comme la nÃ´tre. Il est illusoire de penser que nous ne serons pas affectÃ©s Â», croit Charles Trottier.



Depuis ses dÃ©buts, lâ€™homme dâ€™affaires a investi 1,8 million $ dans la fromagerie, dont 750 000 $ depuis deux ans, entre autres pour construire une nouvelle Ã©table. Et il compte sur sa clientÃ¨le quÃ©bÃ©coise -- plus de 30 000 personnes visitent la fromagerie chaque annÃ©e -- pour survivre.



Contrairement Ã  Charles Trottier, qui dit travailler plus de 105 Ã  110 heures par semaine pour faire tourner la fromagerie avec son associÃ© et une vingtaine dâ€™employÃ©s, Â« Rudy, lui, opÃ©rait seul, avec lâ€™Ã©nergie de la jeunesse Â».



Câ€™est peut-Ãªtre parce quâ€™il devait se battre envers et contre tous que Rudy Ducreux avait surnommÃ© son produit vedette Â« Le Gaulois de Portneuf Â», gagnant dâ€™un prix Caseus (2011), sorte de Jeux olympiques annuels du fromage.



Charles Trottier, co-propriÃ©taire de la Fromagerie Des Grondines, a bien connu Rudy Ducreux, un champion fromager.



Combien dâ€™agriculteurs se suicident?

Â« Je ne sais pas dans quelle mesure le cas de Rudy Ducreux est reprÃ©sentatif de lâ€™Ã©tat psychologique de lâ€™ensemble des producteurs laitiers du QuÃ©bec Â», dit Ginette Lafleur, doctorante au Centre de recherche et dâ€™intervention sur le suicide et lâ€™euthanasie (CRISE) Ã  lâ€™UQAM. Si les fromagers artisans ne transforment quâ€™une goutte de lait produite par les quelque 5 600 fermes laitiÃ¨res du QuÃ©bec, ils sont le porte-Ã©tendard dâ€™une industrie qui gÃ©nÃ¨re prÃ¨s de 30 % de toutes les recettes agricoles de la province.



Selon la doctorante, le mÃ©tier dâ€™agriculteur est reconnu comme l'un des plus Ã  risque de stress Ã  cause dâ€™Ã©lÃ©ments incontrÃ´lables comme la mÃ©tÃ©o. Mais la mondialisation, les traitÃ©s commerciaux, le prix du lait, le prix du quota, lâ€™endettement des entreprises, les changements technologiques, les conflits familiaux, les chicanes de couple ou lâ€™isolement sont tous des facteurs de stress qui sâ€™additionnent et font grimper le taux de la dÃ©tresse psychologique. Â« Jusquâ€™Ã  ce que lâ€™Ã©lastique pÃ¨te Â», explique celle qui a Ã©tudiÃ© le malaise des agriculteurs tant au QuÃ©bec quâ€™en France et en Suisse1.



Toutefois, la seule Ã©tude disponible sur le taux de suicide des agriculteurs quÃ©bÃ©cois indiquait quâ€™il Ã©tait le double de celui des hommes dans la population gÃ©nÃ©rale quÃ©bÃ©coise. Mais cette Ã©tude2 rÃ©alisÃ©e par SantÃ© Canada date de trente ans (1971-1987). Le problÃ¨me, pour obtenir lâ€™heure juste, câ€™est que lâ€™Institut national de la santÃ© publique du QuÃ©bec ne comptabilise pas les suicides par profession. En 2014, 845 QuÃ©bÃ©cois se sont enlevÃ© la vie et, depuis 1981, cette triste statistique annuelle oscille entre 795 et 1284 hommes.



Parmi les pays dÃ©veloppÃ©s, la France sâ€™est toutefois dotÃ©e en 2013 dâ€™un Observatoire national du suicide qui dÃ©nombre 417 suicides chez les hommes agriculteurs entre 2007 Ã  2009, surtout dans les Ã©levages de bovins.



Rudy Ducreux, lâ€™arbre qui cache la forÃªt?



Notre enquÃªte rÃ©vÃ¨le cependant que le phÃ©nomÃ¨ne du suicide des agriculteurs existe bel et bien dans la campagne quÃ©bÃ©coise. Parlez-en Ã  Laurier Gauthier, un voisin de Rudy Ducreux. Lâ€™homme de 67 ans est producteur de lait et copropriÃ©taire avec ses frÃ¨res de la seconde plus grosse Ã©rabliÃ¨re de la Belle Province. Il a offert de nous accompagner Ã  la ferme DucrÃªt.

La vraie raison profonde, les gens partent avec.

â€“ Laurier Gauthier

En chemin, Ã  bord de son camion, M. Gauthier lance devant la ferme dâ€™un de ses voisins. Â« Lui aussi il sâ€™est suicidÃ©. Puis pourtant, il avait de lâ€™argent plein les poches. Il venait de sâ€™acheter une Cadillac. Un bon matin, on apprend quâ€™il sâ€™Ã©tait tirÃ© un coup de 22 en arriÃ¨re des oreilles. Surprise totale Â». Il ajoute avoir connu six personnes, dont cinq producteurs et un employÃ© de ferme, qui se sont enlevÃ© la vie dans un rayon de 12 kilomÃ¨tres de son entreprise.



Quant au geste irrÃ©mÃ©diable de Rudy Ducreux, M. Gauthier lâ€™explique peut-Ãªtre par une charge de travail trop lourde pour un seul homme, mais, Â« la vraie raison profonde, les gens partent avec Â», dit-il. Maire de Saint-Basile durant une trentaine dâ€™annÃ©es, le producteur pointe du doigt lâ€™actuel contexte socio-Ã©conomique comme facteur important de dÃ©tresse psychologique chez les producteurs agricoles. Il reproche Ã  QuÃ©bec, depuis le rÃ¨gne du ministre de lâ€™Agriculture pÃ©quiste Jean Garon (1976-1985), champion de la souverainetÃ© alimentaire, de nommer des ministres de lâ€™Agriculture Ã  temps partiel ou ignorant des enjeux.



Quant au fÃ©dÃ©ral, le producteur se demande jusquâ€™oÃ¹ Ottawa, dans lâ€™actuelle renÃ©gociation de lâ€™ALENA exigÃ©e par le prÃ©sident Donald Trump, est prÃªt Ã  dÃ©fendre la gestion de lâ€™offre et ne pas la sacrifier au profit des secteurs du bois dâ€™Å“uvre, de lâ€™automobile ou de lâ€™aviation.



Nous arrivons Ã  la ferme DucrÃªt. Rudy Ducreux avait achetÃ© en 2004 la ferme de Luc Mailloux, un ex-fromager au lait cru, et frÃ¨re du psychiatre controversÃ© Pierre Â« Doc Â» Mailloux. Sur place, nous sommes accueillis par Connie McLellan, une jeune agricultrice de 28 ans originaire de Nouvelle-Ã‰cosse. Elle hÃ©site Ã  parler au journaliste, selon les conseils de lâ€™avocat engagÃ© par la succession Â« pour ne pas nuire Ã  la vente de la ferme Â», prÃ©vue dâ€™ici lâ€™automne. Le corps de Rudy Ducreux a depuis longtemps Ã©tÃ© rapatriÃ© par la famille.



Connie McLellan, une jeune productrice, s'occupe du troupeau de Rudy Ducreux.



La jeune femme explique avoir Ã©tÃ© recrutÃ©e pour traire le troupeau de 26 bÃªtes. Ã€ part le cliquetis des chaÃ®nes des vaches Ã  lâ€™Ã©table, le silence rÃ¨gne autour de la maison, de la fromagerie, de lâ€™Ã©tabli et des remises dÃ©sertÃ©s. Seul un chat en manque de caresses nous suit dâ€™un bÃ¢timent Ã  lâ€™autre.



Dans les champs adjacents, de la machinerie rouille au milieu de hautes herbes. Et on peut apercevoir de nouvelles plantations dâ€™arbres sur les terres voisines autrefois cultivÃ©es. Comme lâ€™arbre qui cache la forÃªt, le suicide du crÃ©ateur du Gaulois de Portneuf cache un pan de lâ€™agriculture quÃ©bÃ©coise en pÃ©ril.

TEXT:
In mehreren BundeslÃ¤ndern ist das Bildungsniveau der GrundschÃ¼ler massiv gesunken

Eine Studie der Kultusministerkonferenz hat sich die Leistungen in den FÃ¤chern Deutsch und Mathematik angeschaut

GrundschÃ¼ler in Deutschland haben mit immer grÃ¶ÃŸeren Lernschwierigkeiten zu kÃ¤mpfen.

An diesem Freitag stellt die Kultusministerkonferenz (KMK) in Berlin eine Studie Ã¼ber das Niveau in den FÃ¤chern Deutsch und Mathematik vor. Die PrÃ¤sidentin der KMK Susanne Eisenmann sprach von einer wichtigen Standortbestimmung.

Die Studie, die am Nachmittag prÃ¤sentiert wird, zeigt laut baden-wÃ¼rttembergischen Medienberichten, dass das Bildungsniveau vom Jahr 2011 auf 2016 in ganz Deutschland massiv gesunken ist - vor allem in zwei BundeslÃ¤ndern: Bremen und Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg.

Das berichteten die "Heilbronner Stimme" und der "Mannheimer Morgen" am Donnerstag unter Berufung auf SÃ¼dwest-Regierungskreise. Die "SÃ¼dwest Presse" berichtete von einem drohenden "Desaster". â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Die Bildungsnation geht unter? Das ist Unsinn!

Mehr Lehrer sollen das Problem lÃ¶sen

Unmittelbar vor der PrÃ¤sentation der groÃŸen Schulstudie wird besonders der Ruf nach mehr Lehrern fÃ¼r Deutschlands Schulen lauter. "Ohne ausreichend Lehrer kann es keinen Bildungserfolg geben", sagte Hamburgs Schulsenator Ties Rabe (SPD) der Deutschen Presse-Agentur in Berlin.

Rabe sagte, gegen den Lehrermangel seien kurzfristige Schritte und lÃ¤ngerfristige Konzepte nÃ¶tig. "Es ist ein Zukunftsthema, dessen Brisanz sich immer schÃ¤rfer abzeichnet." Bestimmte LÃ¤nder hÃ¤tten erhebliche Probleme, ausreichend Nachwuchs zu finden.

SUMMARY:
Part One... Last week was my favourite week of the year people...no not Christmas.
Finally, we get a week to preach about looking after your eyes so you don't end up with squiffy ones like mine.
It's quite surreal, especially when I'm walking down a busy street in central London, but it's so peaceful and calming.
The Undateables star, living with high functioning autism and severe dyspraxiaAttitudes Haven't Changed?
Hi TopladyTalks here, writer/blogger/wheelchair user who writes about what I see from beneath the 'invisibilty cloak' of my wheelchair!
TEXT:
Prevention Rather Than Cure. Part One... Last week was my favourite week of the year people...no not Christmas. Guess again?! No, not international David Gandy appreciation week....It was National Eye Health Week! Finally, we get a week to preach about looking after your eyes so you don't end up with squiffy ones like mine. Comedian and writer.

What To Expect When You Are (Not) Expecting A Child With Cerebral Palsy William needs 24/7 care, but he loves being with people, whether they are children or 'grown-ups'. If you're (not) expecting a child with cerebral palsy you won't be expecting the feelings of relief, comfort and happiness when you see them build relationships with adults who want to help them as much as you do. Writer & Disability Campaigner

Life In A Wheelchair - The Questions You Always Wanted To Ask Naturally as a newly injured child, my thoughts didn't turn to mortgages or whether I would be able to get a job. At that time, I had no concept of just how expensive having a spinal cord injury could be. I had far more pressing concerns such as: Head of Bolt Burdon Kemp's spinal injury department

Why Having A Hearing Loss Is Not All Bad For me, peace and quiet is just one click away - all I need to do is turn off my hearing aids, or take them out, and everything is muted. It's quite surreal, especially when I'm walking down a busy street in central London, but it's so peaceful and calming. Writer, marketer and avid chocolate muncher. Firm believer in replacing fear of the unknown with curiosity.

Yes, I Take Full Responsibility For This Disease I Can't Control... It has crossed my mind many times that it would be much easier to just not tell people I have epilepsy. But there is always that chance of a seizure, and the risk of something going wrong - or someone doing something wrong - is reduced if we all talk about epilepsy a little bit more and encourage people with epilepsy to do more. If I've decided I can take the risk, you can too. Writer with a tongue-testing name. Condensing the world into frantic words.

I'm Not Going To Let MS Stop Me From Exercising - It's What Keeps Me Fighting I spent a lot of time in the gym when I was teenager. Initially it was more of a social thing, but slowly exercise became a way of life for me. I imagined myself strong and healthy, and assumed I'd always be able to go for runs and lift heavy weights. What I never considered at 16 was that I'd soon be diagnosed with a condition that would force me to rethink exercise entirely. Mum to Dante and MS Society supporter

Just A Drag Queen With No Arms It wasn't long before they took me under their wing and I eventually decided I wanted to do drag as well. With their help and support I chose the name Venus Dimilo after the statue with no arms and started the occasional promotion shift handing out flyers. Just a drag queen with no arms...

How To Have A Life And IBS Suffering from an embarrassing condition can be tough thing for anyone to deal with, but shutting loved ones out is not the solution to your worries. I find that talking to people about my condition reduces the stress and anxiety I get because I'm not trying to hide it. Beauty, fashion, travel and lifestyle blogger

Three Ways To Help People With Tinnitus Have A Better Quality Of Life If I was to tell you that one in ten people had a disability which couldn't be physically seen, but that often prevented them from working - how would you feel? Managing Director, The Tinnitus Clinic

People Think It's Extraordinary That I Work - But Disability Doesn't Have To Be A Barrier When I graduated from university in 2015, I was under the illusion that with a good degree and a strong CV due to all the volunteering that I'd done, I would find a job pretty quickly. This couldn't have been further from the truth. supporter Scope and Virgin Mediaâ€™s Work With Me campaign

My Brittle Bone Condition Won't Stop Me Living Life To The Full My name is Samantha Renke and I am a Lancashire-born actress and public speaker who currently lives in east London. I am a former teacher and trustee for the brittle bone society. I have a genetic condition called osteogenesis imperfecta, more commonly known as brittle bones condition which means I am a full-time wheelchair user, but this most certainly doesn't stop me from living life to the full. Actress and disability campaigner

Going On The Undateables Taught Me I Don't Need To Be Terrified Of Dating If I can take anything away from being on the show I would say it has given me the confidence to go out and enjoy dating. Rather than being terrified of it. I don't know what the future holds for Tanya and I, but if nothing else, I've make a new friend. Engineer and The Undateables star, living with brittle bones

Six 'Socially Unacceptable' Things I Do Because Of My Chronic Illness One of the most frustrating things about chronic illness is the unpredictability of it -- I never know how I'm going to feel. Sometimes I can do stuff, sometimes I can't, and it's so bloody confusing. Even after almost 10 years of health stuff, I still haven't figured it out, and I don't think I ever will. writer, cartoonist, health activist

How I Came Out Of The Undateables Wiser And More Confident This journey has made me a stronger and a more confident person, it may not work for everyone with a disability but I felt it worked for me. I think that the show is a credit to someone like myself because it focuses on who the person is rather than how their disability affects them. To anyone with a disability I say this, this show made me confident and wiser, I got to meet someone great and if you think this show could help you to date then I encourage you to apply. The Undateables star, living with high functioning autism and severe dyspraxia

Attitudes Haven't Changed? What A Surprise As a wheelchair user due to chronic pain, I find the self same discrimination within my own social circle. They sometimes make comments about the appearance of a disabled person in the news and make assumptions about them based on their appearance. Hi TopladyTalks here, writer/blogger/wheelchair user who writes about what I see from beneath the 'invisibilty cloak' of my wheelchair!
TITLE: Everybody

SUMMARY:
The government has been forced into an embarrassing backtrack after admitting Universal Credit claimants need to call a costly helpline to receive welfare payments.
The PMâ€™s spokesperson later said most people claim Universal Credit online and so avoid the charges, while the DWP suggested people had a choice.
However, claimants told HuffPost they are forced to use the 0345 helpline to set up their Universal Credit account in the first place - meaning all recipients are effectively required to use the service.
â€œTo do anything, to set up, to make an appointment you have to ring the Universal Credit line,â€ the 33-year-old from Walsall, West Midlands, said.
PA Archive/PA Images The DWP has admitted Universal Credit claimants do need to use the phone to arrange an initial appointmentA Department for Work and Pensions spokesman told HuffPost on Thursday: â€œNine out of ten people are applying for Universal Credit online.
TEXT:
The government has been forced into an embarrassing backtrack after admitting Universal Credit claimants need to call a costly helpline to receive welfare payments.

The confession came just a day after the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) said claimants could manage accounts entirely online, and only after HuffPost UK confronted officials with detailed accounts of hardship caused by phone fees.

The 55p a minute charge prompted a Commons showdown and was described as a â€œmass injusticeâ€ and â€œgrim beyond beliefâ€ by an influential Labour MP.

â€œJustice calls for a freephone number to be introduced as a matter of urgency,â€ Frank Field, chair of the Commons Work and Pensions Committee, told HuffPost.

HuffPost UK Calls to the Universal Credit helpline cost as much as 55p per minute

It comes after Theresa May fought off demands to scrap the fees after Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn urged her to â€œshow humanityâ€ and cut the call costs.

The PMâ€™s spokesperson later said most people claim Universal Credit online and so avoid the charges, while the DWP suggested people had a choice. â€œ[F]or those who want to call us, they are charged at local rates,â€ it said.

However, claimants told HuffPost they are forced to use the 0345 helpline to set up their Universal Credit account in the first place - meaning all recipients are effectively required to use the service.

Donna Plant Donna Plant revealed she was forced to use the Universal Credit helpline as part of the set up process

Claimant Donna Plant told HuffPost on Thursday that along with using the helpline to set up her account, she is forced to use it every time she wants to re-arrange an appointment or meeting.

â€œTo do anything, to set up, to make an appointment you have to ring the Universal Credit line,â€ the 33-year-old from Walsall, West Midlands, said.

â€œIf you canâ€™t attend an appointment you have to ring the helpline. The job centre donâ€™t really do anything any more. There is no other option.â€

Plant shared a letter with HuffPost which reveals claimants are told in writing to call the 0345 helpline number to re-arrange missed meetings and appointments.

And Plant is not alone. Other people contacted HuffPost to share their accounts of using the helpline either themselves or on the behalf of others.

â€˜30 to 40 minutes on holdâ€™

â€œI was calling on behalf of a friend who because of [Universal Credit] and DWP errors nearly got evicted last year,â€ one person who did not wish to be named said.

â€œOn average the time spent on hold of late has been around 30 to 40 minutes, no matter what time or day you call. For those on low incomes trying to get through it is an awfully high amount [to pay].â€

One person helped by Citizens Advice said: â€œSince being on Universal Credit I have spent hours on the phone and have wasted so much money making these calls.

â€œEvery month they deduct money from my payment so I have to call, explain the situation and then they send it back to me.

â€œItâ€™s really inconvenient and on occasions when my payments have been on a weekend I have been left short and unable to pay my rent and other bills.â€

â€˜How do they think that I can afford to pay 55p a minute?â€™

â€œHow do they think that I can afford to pay 55p a minute to call Universal Credit?â€ Plant added.

â€œIâ€™ve had to call twice this month so far, I needed to see if I could get a budgeting loan. Iâ€™m going to have call them again because an advisor hasnâ€™t got back to me about my budget.â€

In fact, after HuffPost shared the accounts with the DWP, it conceded in a statement that Universal Credit applicants are required to arrange an initial appointment over the phone.

PA Archive/PA Images The DWP has admitted Universal Credit claimants do need to use the phone to arrange an initial appointment

A Department for Work and Pensions spokesman told HuffPost on Thursday: â€œNine out of ten people are applying for Universal Credit online. Once they complete the online process, they are asked to arrange their first Work Coach appointment over the phone.

â€œAfter that point, they can re-arrange appointments and contact their Work Coach via their online journal, or by email.â€

Stephen Lloyd, the Lib Dem DWP spokesperson, told HuffPost: â€œI am not surprised in the slightest that the DWP have had to come back and admit all new UC recipients have to phone the helpline initially, despite saying earlier they did not and that it could be done online.â€

And Field, Labour MP for Birkenhead, added: â€œThe public will be knocked sideways by this mass injustice.

â€œThe Government clearly looks as though it is kicking large numbers of people while theyâ€™re down; people without any money are required to pay for these essential calls just to try and establish a source of income.

â€œItâ€™s grim beyond belief. Justice calls for a freephone number to be introduced as a matter of urgency, to prevent people sliding into destitution.â€

Figures released under freedom of information laws show 55,000 people a week called the Universal Credit helpline during August.

HuffPost revealed on Wednesday that callers to the helpline are not given the option of being called back â€œstraight awayâ€ due to data protection rules.

Our reporter spent 12 and a half minutes on hold before their request for a call back was denied by a call handler.

The call would have cost some people on mobiles Â£7.51, the equivalent of more than 11 percent of the weekly allowance for some claimants.

Criticism of the new welfare policy, which has led to delays in some payments and a reported increase in the use of loan sharks and foodbanks, has mounted as a nationwide rollout nears.
TITLE: DWP Forced To Admit Universal Credit Claimants Need To Call Costly Helpline

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers.
Subscribe here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
OpinionAs incidents of violence against Dalits mount in Gujarat, it is worth recalling the India of BR Ambedkar's dreams, writes Sukhadeo Thorat in The Indian Express.
In the coming weeks and months, evolution of the Catalan crisis is going have serious implications for many other separatist movements in Europe and around the world, writes Gulshan Sachdeva in the Hindustan Times.
In The Telegraph, Lahore-based journalist Mehmal Safraz highlights the systematic persecution of Ahmadias in Pakistan, with a steadily deepening far-Right ideology making it worse.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers. Subscribe here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

Essential HuffPost

The Supreme Court, in a landmark judgment, has ruled that sex with child brides amounts to rape, reading down Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code, which exempted sexual intercourse by a man with his wife, the wife not being under fifteen years of age, from being labelled as rape.

The grand Ram Statue on the banks of River Sarayu in Ayodhya that the Uttar Pradesh government under CM Adityanath is rooting for is a misplaced priority in a state where both healthcare and education need serious attention, argues Sandip Roy.

22-year-old Yedu Krishnan, the first Dalit priest of Kerala, scripted history when he performed prayers at the Manappuram Mahadeva temple at Valanjavattom in Pathanamthitta district on Monday.

Main News

The Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister has stressed the need to "accelerate economic growth and employment over the next six months", while identifying 10 areas in which it will prepare reports and make recommendations to the government over the next few months.

The Allahabad High Court is likely to decide the fate of Rajesh and Nupur Talwar, who are serving a life term for murdering their daughter, Aarushi Talwar, and domestic worker Hemraj in Noida in 2008.

The Reserve Bank of India directed financial companies to make know-your-customer-compliant prepaid payment instruments such as mobile wallets interoperable within the next six months.

Off The Front Page

Identifying real estate as the a sector where maximum the amount of tax evasion takes place, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said there was a strong case to bring it under the ambit of the Goods and Services Tax.

With the Supreme Court reading down the exception to rape of minor married girls in Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code, those who are already in a child marriage will be forced to live separately till the girl turns 18, experts say.

A report by the World Health Organisation and Imperial College, London, published in medical journal The Lancet, stated that obesity rates among the world's children and adolescents increased from less than 1% in 1975 to nearly 6% in girls and nearly 8% in boys in 2016.

Opinion

As incidents of violence against Dalits mount in Gujarat, it is worth recalling the India of BR Ambedkar's dreams, writes Sukhadeo Thorat in The Indian Express.

In the coming weeks and months, evolution of the Catalan crisis is going have serious implications for many other separatist movements in Europe and around the world, writes Gulshan Sachdeva in the Hindustan Times.

In The Telegraph, Lahore-based journalist Mehmal Safraz highlights the systematic persecution of Ahmadias in Pakistan, with a steadily deepening far-Right ideology making it worse.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: The Morning Wrap: SC Delivers A Blow To Child Marriage; Real Estate May Come Under GST
